Award.AwardTitle: Dynamics and Symmetry in Quantum Gravity
Award.AbstractNarration:
An important question facing fundamental physics is how the well-tested laws of Einstein's theory of gravity and quantum mechanics become consistent at the Planck scale -- the question of quantum gravity. This question is of central importance in understanding the origin of our universe, the big bang. Most of the remarkable progress on understanding the big bang has occurred in the context of quantum cosmology: quantum models of highly symmetric, and therefore highly simplified, universes. While these models have a structure guided by the full theory of quantum gravity, they are not directly derived from it as a quantum theory. The present award seeks to close this gap. This will solidify confidence in the predictions of quantum cosmology and also permit its insights to be used to guide future developments of quantum gravity itself. A second part of this research aims to further understand the relation between the relatively well-understood canonical formulation of quantum gravity and the Feynman sum-over-histories formulation, in which space and time are treated in a more unified way.

By allowing graduate students to participate in frontier physics, and to interact with other research groups, this award will have a broad and long-term impact on the development of future scientists. The results of the research will be disseminated to the scientific community through peer reviewed publication and scientific lectures, as well as to the general public through public lectures and other means.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit: 

An important question facing fundamental physics is how the well-tested laws of Einstein's theory of gravity and quantum mechanics become consistent at the Planck scale -- the question of quantum gravity. This question is of central importance in understanding the origin of our universe, the big bang. There is strong observational evidence that, near the big bang, the universe started out in a state which is very close to homogeneous, and in which no direction at any point is special (isotropy). Most of the remarkable progress on understanding the big bang – including ground-breaking calculations of predictions of quantum gravity which are in principle observable - has occurred in the context of quantum cosmology: quantum models of highly symmetric, and therefore highly simplified, universes. While these models have a structure guided by the full theory of quantum gravity, they are not directly derived from it as a quantum theory.

The first outcome of the research funded by this grant is a definition of homogeneity and isotropy in a full theory of quantum gravity, specifically Loop Quantum Gravity (LQG). More precisely, a definition was found which (1.) is “background independent”, that is, is invariant under arbitrary deformations of space (a condition required for it to make sense in any final theory of quantum gravity) (2.) respects the Heisenberg uncertainty principle of quantum mechanics, and (3.) respects the structure of continuum, non-truncated loop quantum gravity, allowing the symmetry to be successfully defined and imposed in this particular theory. Achieving all three of these criteria was highly non-trivial and had never been done before.

This definition of quantum symmetry was used to clarify a number of issues which, in particular, strengthened confidence in Loop Quantum Cosmology (LQC), the prevailing quantum cosmological model based on LQG. This strengthened confidence in LQC can be regarded as a second principal outcome of the research. Indeed, this outcome was confirmed through independent means, again as part of the work of this grant, by directly applying the principle of background independence (invariance under spatial deformations) to show that various technical choices in the construction of LQC and variations thereof, do not matter, and all lead in the end to the same quantum cosmological model, namely that which has been used up until now in the LQC community.

The third principal outcome of this research regards a refinement of the prevailing model of the dynamics of the Feynman sum-over-histories formulation of LQG, in which space and time are treated in a more unified way--- a formulation known as spin-foams. Specifically, the prevailing model of the dynamics --- the so-called `EPRL model’ --- has more than one gravitational sector which interfere with each other in such a way as to produce results which seem to be not consistent with Einstein’s theory of gravity in the large-scale limit. As part of this grant, this prevailing model of dynamics was modified to eliminate all but one gravitational sector in order to correct the problem, leading to a spin-foam model which the PI has named the “proper” spin-foam model. Various consequences of this new model were then calculated, including the predicted statistical correlation between the gravitational field at different pairs of points in flat space-time --- the so-called `graviton propagator’. As was the case with the prior EPRL model, the resulting graviton propagator was found to be consistent with that predicted by linearized quantum gravity, which one expects because one is in the near-flat regime.

 

Broader Impact:

Through partial financial support, this grant enabled four doctoral students and one post-doc to participate in the research described above, contributing in an essential way to the professional development of the next generation of scientists. In addition, the grant in part enabled the PI to engage in other activities of broader impact, specifically (1.) writing two book chapters introducing, to beginning graduate students and scientists in related fields, two research areas in classical and quantum gravity, as well as (2.) giving a public lecture on quantum gravity and his research.
